title: Force on blocks moving around circular wall

content.description: Blocks <math alttext="uppercase A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of masses <math alttext="1.0 kilogram" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1.0</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2.5 kilograms" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2.5</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively, are on a horizontal surface and in contact with a circular vertical wall. The vertical wall makes a circle of radius of <math alttext="1.25 meters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1.25</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both blocks are also in contact with each other as shown in the top view. The horizontal surface has negligible friction, whereas the coefficient of kinetic friction between the vertical wall and the blocks is <math alttext="0.20" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. A force of constant magnitude <math alttext="F" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is being exerted on block <math alttext="uppercase A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> such that both blocks move around the circular wall. The direction of the force is constantly changing such that it is directed tangent to the circular wall.
content.question: If the blocks move at constant speed, and it takes them <math alttext="10 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>10</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to go once around the circle, the magnitude of <math alttext="uppercase F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is most nearly

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
